response:
Based on François de Boisrobert's title, it's possible that this work is an adaptation or original French tragedy from around 1658. We can make educated guesses about historical setting based upon known works by Boissard and general knowledge pertaining to his era.
- The play likely took place during the Baroque period in France (mid-to-late seventeenth century). This fits with both François de Boisrobert's writing style, as well as the publication date of 1658. Furthermore, this was a time when French tragedy gained traction thanks largely to the works and plays by Corneille.
- As for geographic setting - we can glean some clues from the title itself ("Théodore Reyne de Hongrie"). If Théodore is indeed Hungarian (as suggested in the play's name), then it could be possible that this work took place within a Franco-Hungarian historical context. However, François de Boisrobert also wrote other works such as "Le grand festin", which was set on an island called Les Délices ("Delightful Island" or La Belle Île in French). This suggests he may have been inspired by the natural landscapes around France's Atlantic coast.
- It is impossible to determine whether any of Boisrobert’s plays took place at all - indeed, we do not even know that they were ever performed. However if this play was meant as an original work instead of a translation from another author like Corneille or Racine, then it could well have been created entirely for entertainment purposes.

Note: The start and end values for timeframe are estimated based upon François de Boisrobert’s known works. Due to a lack of evidence as to whether Théodore Reyne de Hongrie was performed, this play may never have been set in any specific location or time period beyond its title's inspiration.

Please note that we don't know if the author himself wrote these plays - and indeed he has not received much attention since his death. Furthermore it is impossible for us as an AI to determine whether Théodore Reyne de Hongrie was performed, written solely based upon textual clues such as those provided in this brief excerpt of a play.

Therefore while François de Boisrobert's works may have inspired authors that came after him and he influenced writers like Corneille - there is no way we can confirm if 'Théodore Reyne de Hongrie' was performed or what its original geographic setting might be. 

It should also not go unnoticed how the play’s title refers to Hungarian King, though François de Boisrobert himself wasn't of Hungarian origin nor did he write about Hungary specifically in his other well-known works like Le Grand Festin which instead takes place on an island called Les Délices (La Belle Île) inspired by landscapes around France's Atlantic coast.
